name: Hydrogen
about: Hydrogen (H) is the lightest, most abundant element in the universe, consisting of one proton and one electron. On Earth, it's not found as a free gas but as part of compounds like water (H₂O) or hydrocarbons. Hydrogen is a colorless, odorless, highly flammable gas that serves as a clean energy carrier; when used in a fuel cell, it produces only water, making it a candidate for clean energy solutions in transportation, electricity generation, and industry.

name: Helium
about: Helium (He) is a colorless, odorless, non-toxic, inert, monatomic gas and the first in the noble gas group in the periodic table. It is the second lightest and second most abundant element in the observable universe, primarily formed through nuclear fusion in stars.
EN: Not defined because helium is chemically inert and does not form stable bonds
triplePointTemp: Helium does not have a normal triple point under standard pressure; it remains liquid down to absolute zero at 1 atm
triplePointPressure: Helium does not solidify at 1 atm, so triple point pressure is undefined
dissociationEnergy: Helium exists as a monatomic gas; there is no bond to dissociate

name: Lithium
about: Lithium (Li) is the lightest metal and the least dense solid element. It is a soft, silvery alkali metal that reacts vigorously with water to form lithium hydroxide and hydrogen gas. Lithium has important applications in rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, ceramics, glass, lubricants, and psychiatric medications.

name: Beryllium
about: Beryllium (Be) is a steel-gray, hard, strong, lightweight, and brittle alkaline earth metal. It is a divalent element that occurs naturally only in combination with other elements to form minerals.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Van der Waals radius is not defined because beryllium forms metallic bonds rather than weak intermolecular interactions
triplePointTemp: Not measured; beryllium sublimates before forming a stable liquid at standard pressures
triplePointPressure: Not defined for same reason as above
criticalTemp: Critical temperature is not defined because beryllium does not exist as a stable liquid at normal pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; metallic bonds are not typically described as discrete molecules

name: Boron
about: Boron (B) is a brittle metalloid used in glass, ceramics, detergents, and semiconductors. It has three valence electrons allowing it to form covalent compounds.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Approximate; not precisely measured for solid boron due to complex bonding
triplePointTemp: Not well defined; boron sublimes rather than forming a liquid at normal pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; boron exists as a network solid, not discrete molecules

name: Carbon
about: Carbon (C) is the basis of all known life and exists in several allotropes including graphite, diamond, and graphene. Carbon compounds are central to organic chemistry and energy sources such as coal, oil, and natural gas.
triplePointTemp: Not precisely defined; carbon sublimes at atmospheric pressure instead of forming a liquid
triplePointPressure: Not defined due to sublimation behavior
criticalTemp: Not defined; carbon does not exist as a liquid under normal conditions
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; carbon exists as network solids rather than discrete molecules

name: Nitrogen
about: Nitrogen (N) is a diatomic gas making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere. It is relatively inert due to the strong triple bond in N₂ molecules and is vital for proteins, nucleic acids, and fertilizers.
dissociationEnergy: 945 kJ/mol (energy to break N≡N bond in N₂)

name: Oxygen
about: Oxygen (O) is a diatomic gas essential for life and makes up 21% of Earth's atmosphere. Highly reactive, it forms oxides with most elements and is vital in respiration, combustion, and industrial processes.

name: Fluorine
about: Fluorine (F) is the most electronegative and reactive element, forming compounds with almost all other elements. It is a pale yellow gas used in fluorides, Teflon, refrigerants, and uranium enrichment.

name: Neon
about: Neon (Ne) is a chemically inert noble gas that emits bright reddish-orange light when electrically excited. It is used in neon signs, high-voltage indicators, lasers, and cryogenics.
EN: Not defined; neon is inert and does not form stable bonds
dissociationEnergy: Neon exists as monatomic gas; no bonds to dissociate

name: Sodium
about: Sodium (Na) is a soft, silvery-white, highly reactive alkali metal. It reacts vigorously with water to produce sodium hydroxide and hydrogen gas and is widely used in the chemical industry, in street lighting, and in table salt (sodium chloride).
criticalTemp: Unknown; sodium melts before reaching critical point in normal conditions
critPressure: Unknown; no liquid-gas critical data for metallic sodium
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; metallic bonding in solid metal, not discrete molecules

name: Magnesium
about: Magnesium (Mg) is a shiny gray solid, light but strong, and widely used in alloys, electronics, and fireworks. It is an essential element in biology for photosynthesis and enzymatic reactions.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not well-defined for metallic Mg; van der Waals radius applies mostly to non-metals
triplePointTemp: Not measured; Mg melts to liquid then vaporizes without a stable triple point at 1 atm
criticalTemp: Not defined; metal vaporizes before reaching liquid-gas equilibrium
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; metallic bonding rather than discrete molecules

name: Aluminium
about: Aluminium (Al) is a lightweight, silvery-white metal, resistant to corrosion due to a thin oxide layer. It is used in packaging, construction, aerospace, and electrical wiring.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; metal sublimes or melts to liquid under normal pressure

name: Silicon
about: Silicon (Si) is a hard, brittle metalloid essential for semiconductors, glass, ceramics, and cement. It has a tetrahedral crystal structure and forms a wide variety of compounds.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not precisely defined; silicon exists as a network solid
triplePointTemp: Not well defined; silicon sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
criticalTemp: Not defined; silicon does not form a stable liquid-gas equilibrium under standard conditions
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; silicon exists as a network solid

name: Phosphorus
about: Phosphorus (P) is a highly reactive non-metal used in fertilizers, detergents, matches, and biological molecules like DNA and ATP. It exists in several allotropic forms, including white, red, and black phosphorus.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not well defined; varies with allotrope
triplePointTemp: Not well defined; phosphorus allotropes differ in melting behavior
criticalTemp: Not defined; phosphorus sublimes rather than forming liquid under normal pressure
dissociationEnergy: Varies; for P₄ molecule, approx. 267 kJ/mol (P–P bonds)

name: Sulfur
about: Sulfur (S) is a yellow, non-metallic element widely used in fertilizers, chemicals, and sulfuric acid production. It exists in several allotropes, primarily S₈ rings.

name: Chlorine
about: Chlorine (Cl) is a yellow-green diatomic gas highly reactive and used in disinfectants, PVC production, and chemical synthesis.

name: Argon
about: Argon (Ar) is a colorless, odorless, inert noble gas used in lighting, welding, and as an inert atmosphere in chemical processes.
EN: Not defined; argon is chemically inert
dissociationEnergy: Argon is monatomic; no bonds to dissociate

name: Potassium
about: Potassium (K) is a soft, highly reactive alkali metal that reacts vigorously with water. It is essential for biological processes in plants and animals.
criticalTemp: Unknown; potassium vaporizes before reaching liquid-gas equilibrium

name: Calcium
about: Calcium (Ca) is a soft, silvery-white alkaline earth metal essential for biological functions like bone formation. It is also used in alloys, cement, and metallurgy.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not defined; applies mostly to non-metals
triplePointTemp: Not measured; metal melts before reaching triple equilibrium

name: Scandium
about: Scandium (Sc) is a silvery-white metallic element that is the first of the transition metals. It was historically classified as a rare-earth element and is used in aerospace components and sports equipment.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; scandium forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; scandium sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; scandium exists as a metal

name: Titanium
about: Titanium (Ti) is a lustrous transition metal known for its high strength, low density, and corrosion resistance. It is widely used in aerospace, medical devices, and jewelry.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; titanium forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; titanium sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; titanium exists as a metal

name: Vanadium
about: Vanadium (V) is a hard, silvery-grey, malleable transition metal. It is used in the production of strong steel alloys and has applications in batteries and catalysts.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; vanadium forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; vanadium sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; vanadium exists as a metal

name: Chromium
about: Chromium (Cr) is a hard, silvery-grey, lustrous transition metal known for its high corrosion resistance and hardness. It is widely used in plating and alloy production.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; chromium forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; chromium sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; chromium exists as a metal

name: Manganese
about: Manganese (Mn) is a hard, brittle, silvery metal often found in combination with iron. It is used in steel production, aluminum alloys, batteries, and as a trace nutrient in agriculture. Manganese exhibits multiple oxidation states, making it important in catalysis and chemical reactions.
triplePointTemp: not available; metal does not have a known triple point
criticalTemp: not defined; metals do not have a typical critical point

name: Iron
about: Iron (Fe) is a metal in the first transition series. It is the most widely used metal, primarily in the form of steel, which is an alloy of iron and carbon. Iron is essential for blood production in humans and is the most abundant element by mass in the Earth's inner and outer core.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; iron forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; iron sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; iron exists as a metal

name: Cobalt
about: Cobalt (Co) is a hard, ferromagnetic metal with a high melting point. It is used in alloys, batteries, and as a catalyst. Cobalt is also a trace element in the human body.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; cobalt forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; cobalt sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; cobalt exists as a metal

name: Nickel
about: Nickel (Ni) is a silvery-white metal with a slight golden tinge. It is hard and ductile and is widely used in alloys, particularly in stainless steel, and in batteries.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; nickel forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; nickel sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; nickel exists as a metal

name: Copper
about: Copper (Cu) is a reddish-orange metal known for its high thermal and electrical conductivity. It has been used by humans for thousands of years in tools, coins, and electrical wiring.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not applicable; copper forms metallic bonds
triplePointTemp: Not defined; copper sublimes rather than forming a liquid at standard pressure
dissociationEnergy: Not applicable; copper exists as a metal

name: Zinc
about: Zinc (Zn) is a bluish-white transition metal that is relatively abundant in Earth's crust. It is primarily used in galvanization (coating iron and steel to prevent rusting), alloys like brass, and in biological systems as a vital nutrient.

name: Gallium
about: Gallium (Ga) is a soft, silvery metal that melts just above room temperature. It is used in semiconductors, LEDs, and solar panels.

name: Germanium
about: Germanium (Ge) is a brittle, gray-white metalloid used in semiconductors, fiber optics, and infrared optics.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; solid-liquid equilibrium occurs under controlled conditions

name: Arsenic
about: Arsenic is a toxic metalloid with atomic number 33. It occurs naturally in many minerals and is used in alloys and semiconductors.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; sublimation occurs before liquid-gas equilibrium

name: Selenium
about: Selenium is a nonmetal with atomic number 34. It has various physical appearances and is used in electronics and glassmaking.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; solid-liquid equilibrium occurs under controlled conditions

name: Bromine
about: Bromine is a halogen with atomic number 35. It is a volatile red-brown liquid at room temperature and is used in flame retardants.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; liquid-gas equilibrium occurs under controlled conditions

name: Krypton
about: Krypton is a noble gas with atomic number 36. It is colorless, odorless, and used in lighting and photography.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; gas-liquid equilibrium occurs under controlled conditions

name: Rubidium
about: Rubidium is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal with atomic number 37. It is highly reactive and used in research, electronics, and atomic clocks.

name: Strontium
about: Strontium is a soft, silvery alkaline earth metal used in fireworks, magnets, and in refining zinc.

name: Yttrium
about: Yttrium is a silvery transition metal used in LEDs, phosphors, and superconductors. It has atomic number 39.

name: Zirconium
about: Zirconium is a lustrous gray transition metal used in nuclear reactors, ceramics, and alloys. It has atomic number 40.

name: Niobium
about: Niobium is a ductile, gray transition metal used in superalloys, superconducting materials, and electronics.

name: Molybdenum
about: Molybdenum is a silvery transition metal used in steel alloys, lubricants, and electronics.

name: Technetium
about: Technetium is a silvery-gray radioactive transition metal, the lightest element with no stable isotopes, used in medical imaging.
triplePointTemp: Not defined; radioactive decay makes equilibrium difficult

name: Ruthenium
about: Ruthenium is a rare, hard transition metal used in electronics, alloys, and catalysts.

name: Rhodium
about: Rhodium is a rare, silvery-white transition metal known for its high reflectivity and corrosion resistance, used in catalytic converters and jewelry.

name: Palladium
about: Palladium is a rare, silvery-white transition metal used in catalytic converters, electronics, and jewelry.

name: Silver
about: Silver is a soft, white, lustrous transition metal used in jewelry, electronics, and photography.

name: Cadmium
about: Cadmium is a soft, bluish-white transition metal used in batteries, pigments, coatings, and as a corrosion-resistant metal.

name: Indium
about: Indium is a soft, silvery post-transition metal used in electronics, touchscreens, and low-melting alloys.

name: Tin
about: Tin is a silvery post-transition metal used in alloys, coatings, solder, and electronics.

name: Antimony
about: Antimony is a brittle metalloid used in alloys, flame retardants, and semiconductors.

name: Tellurium
about: Tellurium is a brittle metalloid used in alloys, thermoelectric devices, and semiconductors.

name: Iodine
about: Iodine is a halogen, a dark-gray/purple solid that sublimes easily, used in medicine, nutrition, and photography.

name: Xenon
about: Xenon is a colorless, odorless, noble gas used in lighting, medical imaging, and ion propulsion systems.

name: Cesium
about: Cesium is a soft, gold-colored alkali metal used in atomic clocks, photoelectric cells, and vacuum tubes.

name: Barium
about: Barium is a soft, silvery alkaline-earth metal used in fireworks, drilling fluids, and X-ray contrast agents.

name: Lanthanum
about: Lanthanum is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal used in optics, catalysts, and nickel-metal hydride batteries.

name: Hafnium
about: Hafnium is a hard, silvery metal used in nuclear control rods, alloys, and high-temperature ceramics.

name: Tantalum
about: Tantalum is a hard, corrosion-resistant metal used in electronics, surgical implants, and alloys.

name: Tungsten
about: Tungsten is a dense, hard metal with the highest melting point of all metals, used in light bulb filaments, cutting tools, and alloys.

name: Rhenium
about: Rhenium is a rare, silvery metal with one of the highest melting points, used in superalloys and catalysts.

name: Osmium
about: Osmium is a dense, hard, bluish-gray metal used in fountain pen tips, electrical contacts, and alloys.

name: Iridium
about: Iridium is a dense, hard, brittle, silvery-white metal used in high-temperature applications, electrical contacts, and crucibles.

name: Platinum
about: Platinum is a dense, malleable, highly unreactive precious metal used in jewelry, catalytic converters, and laboratory equipment.

name: Gold
about: Gold is a soft, yellow, highly ductile and malleable metal used in jewelry, electronics, dentistry, and as a financial standard.

name: Mercury
about: Mercury is a heavy, silvery d-block element that is liquid at room temperature, used in thermometers, barometers, and electrical switches.

name: Thallium
about: Thallium is a soft, gray post-transition metal used in electronics, low-melting alloys, and historically in rodenticides and optical systems.

name: Lead
about: Lead is a heavy, soft, malleable, bluish-gray metal used in batteries, shielding, and historically in paints and pipes.

name: Bismuth
about: Bismuth is a brittle, silvery-white metal with a pinkish tint, used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, alloys, and fire detectors.

name: Polonium
about: Polonium is a highly radioactive metalloid discovered by Marie Curie, used in anti-static devices and research; it is extremely toxic.

name: Astatine
about: Astatine is a rare, radioactive halogen with properties similar to iodine; it is used primarily in research and has no significant commercial applications.
vanDeWaalsRadius: Not well-defined due to extreme rarity

name: Radon
about: Radon is a radioactive noble gas formed from the decay of radium; it is colorless, odorless, and highly toxic, used only in research and radiation therapy.

name: Francium
about: Francium is a highly radioactive alkali metal, extremely rare and unstable, with no significant commercial applications. It is predicted to behave similarly to cesium.

name: Radium
about: Radium is a highly radioactive alkaline-earth metal, historically used in luminous paints and medical treatments. It is highly toxic and reactive.

name: Actinium
about: Actinium is a radioactive metal in the actinide series, used as a neutron source and in scientific research.

name: Rutherfordium
about: Rutherfordium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Ernest Rutherford. It was first synthesized in 1964 by bombarding californium with carbon nuclei.

name: Dubnium
about: Dubnium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after the town of Dubna, Russia. It was first synthesized in 1968 by bombarding californium with nitrogen nuclei. Due to its extreme radioactivity and short half-life, it has no practical applications and is used only for scientific research.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to tantalum

name: Seaborgium
about: Seaborgium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Glenn T. Seaborg. It was first synthesized in 1974 by bombarding californium with oxygen nuclei. It has no practical applications and exists only in laboratory conditions.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to tungsten

name: Bohrium
about: Bohrium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Niels Bohr. First synthesized in 1981, it has no practical applications due to extreme radioactivity and short half-life.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to rhenium

name: Hassium
about: Hassium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after the German state of Hesse. First synthesized in 1984, it is extremely unstable and exists only for fractions of a second in laboratory conditions.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to osmium

name: Meitnerium
about: Meitnerium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Lise Meitner. First synthesized in 1982, it is highly unstable and used only in laboratory research.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to iridium

name: Darmstadtium
about: Darmstadtium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Darmstadt, Germany. It was first synthesized in 1994 and has no practical applications due to extreme instability.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to platinum

name: Roentgenium
about: Roentgenium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Wilhelm Röntgen, discoverer of X-rays. First synthesized in 1994, it has no practical applications due to extreme radioactivity.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to gold

name: Copernicium
about: Copernicium is a synthetic, radioactive transition metal named after Nicolaus Copernicus. It was first synthesized in 1996 and is highly unstable, with no practical applications.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to mercury

name: Nihonium
about: Nihonium is a synthetic, radioactive post-transition metal named after Japan (Nihon). First synthesized in 2003, it is extremely unstable and has no practical applications.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to thallium

name: Flerovium
about: Flerovium is a synthetic, radioactive post-transition metal named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions in Russia. First synthesized in 1998, it is highly unstable and exists only in laboratory conditions.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to lead

name: Moscovium
about: Moscovium is a synthetic, radioactive post-transition metal named after Moscow, Russia. First synthesized in 2003, it is highly unstable and has no practical applications.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to bismuth

name: Livermorium
about: Livermorium is a synthetic, radioactive post-transition metal named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. First synthesized in 2000, it is extremely unstable and has no practical applications.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to polonium

name: Tennessine
about: Tennessine is a synthetic, radioactive halogen named after the state of Tennessee, USA. First synthesized in 2010, it is extremely unstable and has no practical applications.
atomicRadius: Not defined; estimated similar to astatine

name: Oganesson
about: Oganesson is a synthetic, radioactive noble gas named after Yuri Oganessian. First synthesized in 2002, it is highly unstable, and only a few atoms have ever been produced. It has no practical applications.

name: Cerium
about: Cerium is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal used in catalytic converters, glass polishing, and alloying.

name: Praseodymium
about: Praseodymium is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal used in magnets, glasses, and alloys.

name: Neodymium
about: Neodymium is a silvery rare-earth metal used in strong permanent magnets, lasers, and glass coloring.

name: Promethium
about: Promethium is a radioactive rare-earth metal with no stable isotopes, used in luminous paint and nuclear batteries.

name: Samarium
about: Samarium is a silvery rare-earth metal used in magnets, nuclear reactors, and catalysts.

name: Europium
about: Europium is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal used in phosphors, LEDs, and nuclear control rods.

name: Gadolinium
about: Gadolinium is a silvery rare-earth metal used in MRI contrast agents, magnets, and nuclear reactors.

name: Terbium
about: Terbium is a silvery rare-earth metal used in solid-state devices, phosphors, and magnet applications.

name: Dysprosium
about: Dysprosium is a rare-earth metal used in magnets, lasers, and nuclear reactors due to its high magnetic susceptibility.

name: Holmium
about: Holmium is a rare-earth metal used in nuclear control rods, lasers, and magnetic applications.

name: Erbium
about: Erbium is a silvery rare-earth metal used in lasers, fiber optics, and nuclear technology.

name: Thulium
about: Thulium is a silvery rare-earth metal used in lasers and portable X-ray devices.

name: Ytterbium
about: Ytterbium is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal used in lasers, atomic clocks, and specialized alloys.

name: Lutetium
about: Lutetium is the last rare-earth element, a silvery-white metal used in catalysts, PET scan detectors, and specialized alloys.

name: Thorium
about: Thorium is a radioactive actinide metal used as a nuclear fuel and in high-temperature ceramics.

name: Protactinium
about: Protactinium is a dense, radioactive actinide metal used primarily in scientific research. It is highly toxic and has no significant commercial applications.

name: Uranium
about: Uranium is a dense, radioactive actinide metal used as fuel in nuclear reactors and in nuclear weapons. It is highly toxic and reactive.

name: Neptunium
about: Neptunium is a radioactive actinide metal used mainly in nuclear science and research. It has no significant commercial applications.

name: Plutonium
about: Plutonium is a radioactive actinide metal used as fuel in nuclear reactors and weapons. It is highly toxic and reactive.

name: Americium
about: Americium is a radioactive actinide metal used in smoke detectors, industrial gauges, and research. It is highly toxic and artificially produced.

name: Curium
about: Curium is a radioactive actinide metal used primarily in scientific research and in alpha particle sources. It is highly toxic and synthetic.

name: Berkelium
about: Berkelium is a radioactive actinide metal used mainly in research. It is highly toxic and synthetic.

name: Californium
about: Californium is a radioactive actinide metal used as a neutron source and in scientific research. It is synthetic and highly toxic.

name: Einsteinium
about: Einsteinium is a synthetic, highly radioactive actinide metal used only in scientific research due to its extreme radioactivity and scarcity.

name: Fermium
about: Fermium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide metal with no practical applications. It is used only in scientific research and is highly unstable.

name: Mendelevium
about: Mendelevium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide metal named after Dmitri Mendeleev, the creator of the periodic table. It was first synthesized in 1955 by bombarding einsteinium with alpha particles.

name: Nobelium
about: Nobelium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide metal named after Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite. It was first synthesized in 1958 and is produced by bombarding curium with carbon nuclei.

name: Lawrencium
about: Lawrencium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide metal named after Ernest Lawrence, the inventor of the cyclotron. It was first synthesized in 1961 by bombarding californium with boron nuclei.
